<h2>#03 - Improve Nested Conditionals</h2> <blockquote><p>2016-01-03 by <a href="https://github.com/AlbertoFuente">AlbertoFuente</a></p></blockquote> <p>How can we improve and make more efficient nested <code>if</code> statement in javascript.</p> <p><code>javascript if (color) { if (color === &#39;black&#39;) { printBlackBackground(); } else if (color === &#39;red&#39;) { printRedBackground(); } else if (color === &#39;blue&#39;) { printBlueBackground(); } else if (color === &#39;green&#39;) { printGreenBackground(); } else { printYellowBackground(); } } </code></p> <p>One way to improve the nested <code>if</code> statement would be using the <code>switch</code> statement. Although it is less verbose and is more ordered, It&#39;s not recommended to use it because it&#39;s so difficult to debug errors, here&#39;s <a href="https://toddmotto.com/deprecating-the-switch-statement-for-object-literals/">why</a>.</p> <p><code>javascript switch(color) { case &#39;black&#39;: printBlackBackground(); break; case &#39;red&#39;: printRedBackground(); break; case &#39;blue&#39;: printBlueBackground(); break; case &#39;green&#39;: printGreenBackground(); break; default: printYellowBackground(); } </code></p> <p>But what if we have a conditional with several checks in each statement? In this case, if we like to do less verbose and more ordered, we can use the conditional <code>switch</code>. If we pass <code>true</code> as parameter to the <code>switch</code> statement, It allows us to put a conditional in each case.</p> <p><code>javascript switch(true) { case (typeof color === &#39;string&#39; &amp;&amp; color === &#39;black&#39;): printBlackBackground(); break; case (typeof color === &#39;string&#39; &amp;&amp; color === &#39;red&#39;): printRedBackground(); break; case (typeof color === &#39;string&#39; &amp;&amp; color === &#39;blue&#39;): printBlueBackground(); break; case (typeof color === &#39;string&#39; &amp;&amp; color === &#39;green&#39;): printGreenBackground(); break; case (typeof color === &#39;string&#39; &amp;&amp; color === &#39;yellow&#39;): printYellowBackground(); break; } </code></p> <p>But we must always avoid having several checks in every condition, avoiding use of <code>switch</code> as far as possible and take into account that the most efficient way to do this is through an <code>object</code>.</p> <p><code></code>`javascript var colorObj = { &#39;black&#39;: printBlackBackground, &#39;red&#39;: printRedBackground, &#39;blue&#39;: printBlueBackground, &#39;green&#39;: printGreenBackground, &#39;yellow&#39;: printYellowBackground };</p> <p>if (color in colorObj) { colorObj<a href="">color</a>; } <code></code>`</p> <p>Here you can find more information about <a href="http://www.nicoespeon.com/en/2015/01/oop-revisited-switch-in-js/">this</a>.</p>
